text: Retro theme, played nice Cantonese songs. Food is good. We had truffle char siew bun, emerald salted lava bun , siew mai har kao, wanton and pork chop noodles.  I would say all is good, worth the try and calories! Highly recommend this place.

I happened to pass by and found the menu intriguing. We ordered the lemon chicken rice and a salted fish meat patty rice. The lemon chicken was overwhelmingly sour, lacking the expected balance of sweet and sour flavors. However, the real surprise was their tea—smooth, well-brewed, and free from the harsh, over-steeped bitterness often found elsewhere.

The ambiance, though lively, felt somewhat cramped due to the tight table arrangement. Service-wise, certain corners of the restaurant seemed overlooked, with waitstaff occasionally missing diners in less visible spots. A bit more attentiveness in these areas would enhance the overall experience.

Great food and service! I especially love their polo bun and Arabica coffee—absolutely delicious. The serving speed is impressively fast, making it a perfect spot for a quick yet satisfying meal. The store's HK-style design adds a unique charm, making it a cozy place to enjoy with family and friends. It's also a fantastic spot for taking photos and soaking in the lively atmosphere. Highly recommend!

Happened to pass by this dim sum place located on 2nd floor hence easier to miss.

Food was ok, nothing spectacular.

Service was prompt, average.

Ambience was a throwback to 80s, 90s with accompanying Cantonese music. Was good!

visited this restaurant during holiday, expected to wait for a seat. Food was ok, not impressive, but decent.

It’s located on the second floor, which could pose a safety concern, especially for elderly guests, as the staircase area gets crowded with people going in and out.
